chapter.title: RPM Command Reference
chapter.para: This appendix covers the syntax of the command-line options for the rpm and rpmbuild commands.

sect1.title: The rpm Command
sect1.para: The rpm command is the workhorse of the RPM system. The following sections cover options for the major operations with the rpm command.
Table A-1 lists the query options for the rpm command.

sect2.title: Verify options
sect2.para: The rpm command can verify packages. This involves comparing all files installed by the package with the information in the RPM database, and looking for differences or missing files.

sect1.title: The rpmbuild Command
sect1.para: The rpmbuild command builds RPMs. Most of the options are duplicated. The options that begin with –b build from a spec file, and the options that begin with –t build from a compressed tar archive, commonly called a tarball.

sect2.title: Building from a spec file
sect2.para: Table A-8 lists the rpmbuild options for building RPMs from a spec file.
Table A-8 Options for building RPMs from a spec file

entry.para: Build all, both a binary and source RPM

Prepare for building a binary RPM, by executing the build commands through the %prep section and stopping
Execute the build commands through the %install section and stop
Check the listing of files for the RPM

sect2.para: Each of these options requires the name of a spec file at the end of the command line.

sect2.para: Table A-9 lists the rpmbuild options for working with a compressed tar archive.

sect2.para: Each of these options requires the name of a compressed tar archive at the end of the command line. The tar archive must contain a valid spec file inside the archive.
